thesis.description: Collections of material were made throughout the year from October 1916 to October 1917 at various points in Passamaquoddy Bay and the adjoining waters of the Bay of Fundy. Careful examination of these has revealed the presence of eighty-two species, representative of twentysix genera. Material collected during the different months aas found to vary greatly. [...]
thesis.creator: Fritz, Clara W.
thesis.subject: Botany.
thesis.title: Plankton diatoms in the vicinity of St Andrew's, N.B.

thesis.description: The study of the weathering and slow combustion of coal together with the allied subject of spontaneous combustion has for many years been the object of the experiments of various investigators on both sides of the Atlantic. The reasons why these subjects have been given so much attention are well set forth in papers by Parr-Wheeler; J.B de Hart, and E.E. Billington, and need not be further commented upon here. Sufficit to say that they are of sufficient importance to warrant any amount of investigation, and that although a great deal of valuable work hae been done, especially in France and England and more recently in the United States and Canada, the investigation is, as yet, by no means complete. [...]
thesis.creator: Cameron, Alan E.
thesis.subject: Mining Engineering.
thesis.title: The slow combustion of coal.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: One hears a great deal of talk nowadays about the English Romantic Movement of the nineteenth century. It is called a "Revival", but many who do not know of what it is a revival still continue to regard the nineteenth century as the only preserve for tracking down romanticism. But there are other happy hunting-grounds in English literature for the romanticist-hunter. Romanticism is not an exotic on English soil, but a truly native growth. The poets of every century, except the eighteenth, have been eminently romantic, and whenever an attempt has been made to "guide the stream of poetry through artificial channels" of classicism, the native instinct has very soon asserted itself and led it back to its river-bed. [...]
thesis.creator: Braeuer, Mary A.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Spencer and romanticism.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The importance of agricultural education in the public schools of our rural districts was never more appreciated than it is to-day. The Province of Quebec has at last realized that to maintain its rank as a province possessing an efficient educational system it must adopt measures which will place the subject of nature study and agriculture upon a stronger and more permanent basis. The latest movements of our educational authorities have all tended in that direction and many progressive measures have been adopted to see that the subject receives its adequate share of support. [...]
thesis.creator: McOuat, J. Egbert.
thesis.subject: Rural schools.
Agricultural Education.
Agricultural education.
thesis.title: A study of rural school conditions in Québec in so far as they affect agricultural education : containing suggestions as to improvements in these conditions, and the possibility of introducing a system of agricultural education suitable to this province by bringing about such improvements.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: "The Pacific Ocean, its shores, its islands, and the vast region beyond, will become the chief theatre of events in the world's great hereafter (1)." This was a prophesy of William H. Seward, fifty years ago. In our,own time, Theodore Roosevelt has expressed the same belief: "The Mediterranean era", he says, "died with the discovery of America. The Atlantic era is now at the height of its develop1ment and must soon exhaust the resources at its command. The Pacific era, destined to be tbe greatest of all is just at the dawn." And President Taft said in the Summer of 1909, "The Problem of the Pacific is the greatest problem now before the American people" (3). [...]
thesis.creator: Thomson, Herbert F.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: Canada's relations with China.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Henry George (1) and his followers, advocated a policy, whereby all public revenue, national and local, would be obtained, by appropriating as nearly as may be all the rental value of natural opportunities without regard to improvements. This he called The Single Tax (2). His argument is based upon a distinction between wealth produced by individual effort (wages and interest) and that which results from the aid given by the community as a whole, (economic rent), and may be briefly summarized as follows:- Land being public property and by right belonging to all the people of the country in which it is situated, just as air and sunlight belongs to all individuals in common, one generation has no right to alienate its title so as to affect the title of the next; but, private use and occupancy of land is right and indispensable. [...]
thesis.creator: Stalker, Archibald.
thesis.subject: Economics & Political Science.
Real property tax -- Canada.
Taxation -- Canada.
thesis.title: Taxation of land values in western Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The following paper describes an investigation of the magnetic and electrical properties of some specimens of iron wire of different degrees of purity and hardness. Magnetic Properties. The chief information sought in this part of the investigation was the manner in which the various magnetic constants varied with the character of the iron, and to whatextent they were changed by annealing the specimen. The magnetic quantities under observation were induction, permeability, hysteresis loss, and Steinmetz coefficient. [...]

thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Magnetic and electrical properties of pure iron wire.

thesis.description: In the practice of artificial incubation, which is of extremely ancient origin, there are involved the factors of temperature, turning the eggs, moisture and ventilation, in the study of which particularly the last two factors, the results have constituted a source of special study, the results secured in the studies of the moisture and ventilation factors have not been as conclusive as in studies based on the factors of temperature and turning the eggs. thesis.description: In a large part of his work Plato undoubtedly shows a very great contempt for conventional or common morality. He also elevates the virtue of the philosopher to the highest possible plane. On the other hand, it is undeniable that he recognizes in a very pronounced and definite fashion the value of certain non-intellectual virtues; and in the Republic, as well as in several of the earlier dialogues, there is an acknowledgement of the possibility of good conduct without the possession of that knowledge which is peculiar to the philosopher. [...]
thesis.creator: Melvin, Margaret G.
thesis.contributor: Caldwell, W. & Hickson, J. & Harkness, J. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: Philosophy.
thesis.title: The ideal of courage in Plato.

[...]

thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: The resistance of wheat varieties to Puccinia graminis.

thesis.description: In the following thesis it has been my purpose to deal with the religious philosophy of Augustine as comprehensively as the name of thesis would allow, at the same time striving to keep clear of the dangerous shoals of theological controversies which have revolved about Augustinian doctrines even in recent years. Fortunately for Christianity, Augustine was more than a systematiser of previous Christian doctrines and philosophical ideas. He penetrated deep down into the problem of the religious consciousness and brought to the study a mind which deserves the praise given it in the past on account of its originality, fully as well as the large field which occupied its attention. [...]
thesis.creator: Robinson, Bernard S.
thesis.subject: Divinity.
thesis.title: The philosophy of religion as represented in Augustine.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The object of this research was to show the possibility of makine steel direct, from iron ore in the electric furnace. The idea that steel could be so made occurred to Mr. J. W. Evans, of Belleville, Ont., in 1904. His method was to smelt titaniferous ores in a crucible shaped furnace, of the arc type. He allowed the gases evolved to be wasted. Dr. Stansfield, of McGill University, thought that these gases might be used for preheating the furnace charge. Together, they, (Evans and Stansfield) devised what is knovm as the "Evans-Stgnsfield Process." [...]
thesis.creator: Porter, Cecil G.
thesis.subject: Metallurgical Engineering.
thesis.title: The direct production of steel from iron ore by theEvans-Stansfield process.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In connection with work previously reported (1) on the influence of internal secretions on the formation of bile a study of the blood pressure was made. The object of this was two-fold; to observe the effect on blood pressure of the particular gland substance being studied, and to determine what relation, if any, existed between blood pressure changes and the amount of bilesecreted after a gland substance had been administered intravenously. The following gland substances were employed: Mammary, orchic, ovarian, pancreatic, splenic, thymic,and thyroid. [...]
thesis.creator: Downs, Ardrey W.
thesis.contributor: Hays, Georege & Messrs, L. & Notkin, M. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: THE INFLUENCE OF INTERNAL SECRETIONS ON BLOOD PRESSURE AND THE FORMATION OF BILE.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Modern water concentration of sand sizes is practically confined to riffled jerking tables of the Wilfley type. The original Wilfley table was invented in 1895, but long before this time, the essential elements, riffling and jerking, were known to the art of concentration, Tables such as Rittinger's and Lampert's had one or other of these factors, but were never of paramount importance, and it was the combination of these factors bY Wilfley, which completely revolutionised table concentration. [...]
thesis.creator: Anderson, Clayton E.
thesis.subject: Mining Engineering.
thesis.title: The effect of changes in the design and adjustments of concentrating tables of the Wilfley type and the relation of such changes to the character and efficiency of operation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Ever since the colon bacillus was isolated by Escherich in 1856 from the dejecta of a breast-fed infant and subsequently, in 1884, from the feces of a cholera patient, and it was shortly afterwards found to be a normal inhabitant of the intestinaltract of man and animals, the colon bacteria have formed a nucleus around which the investigations of scientists have centred. [...]
thesis.creator: Anderson, Marian.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
thesis.title: On the relative rate of dextrose fermentation of generations of colon bacteria grown on sugar-free media.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: To the student of today the term 'Historical Truth' conveys an idea quite different from that conveyed by the same term 100 years ago. Prior to the first quarter of the 19th century, as Lord Acton points out, the attitude of the historian was relatively uncritical; and his methods were in sharp contrast to the methods of modern research. Moreover the amount of material available has been so increased that this in itself makes for a much greater degree of completeness. [...]
thesis.creator: McBain, Alexander R.
thesis.contributor: Macmillan, C. & Moyse, C. & Walter, H. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Historical truth of English chronicle history plays.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Experiments were undertaken by Mr. C. McL. Pitts in 1909 at McGill University with the object of measuring the secondary stresses in a small warren Truss made for the purpose. The results were submitted to the University in the form of a thesis. Mr. Pitts concludes: "This investigation clearly demonstrates the importance of considering the secondary stresses in all bridge construction in which the rivetted or rigid joint is used. It further shows the nature of the subject to be such as to forbid of a quick determination of these stresses, and the impossibility of deducing definite rules or formulae". [...]
thesis.creator: Lamb, Henry M.
thesis.subject: Engineering.
thesis.title: An experimental investigation of the secondary stresses in a fourteen foot Warren truss.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In a previous communication from this laboratory (Walker and Krieble, J. Chem. Soc.95,1457) it was proved that the rotation of a racemised amygdalin solution is independent of thenature and of the concentration of the alkali and that the equilibrium point is independent of the temperature and of the concentration of the amygdalin. It was pointed out that racemic amygdalin could be partially resolved into its optical isomers. L-amygdalin or ordinary amygdalin was obtained pure from the racemic by recrystallization from aqueous alcohol and afterwards from water. [...]
thesis.creator: Krieble, Vernon K.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Amygdalins and their inter-reactions with emulsin.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In the eighteenth century literary forgeries were common to a very exceptional degree, more especially in England and in Scotland. The desire to practise that particular type ofdeception seems to have been in the air, though the age was slow to detect the majority of those frauds, which, as would be expected, vary markedly in their importance and complexity. Most of them were contrived by men young in years, some of whom were endowed with genius, a few of whom possessed talent, and yet others who could boast of neither. The reason for their prevalence at that particular period cannot be assigned readily, apart from the fact that the age was unique in its credulity, inclined to believe almost any hoax. [...]
thesis.creator: Irving, William G.
thesis.contributor: Lafleur, P & Moyse, C. & Macmillan, C. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Literary forgeries of the eighteenth century.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: On a souvent reproché aux frames de Victor Hugo d'avoir un élément développé aux dépens de lélément dramatique. Je me propose, d'abord, dans cette thèse, de faire ressortir les qualités lyriques de ses frames et ensuite d'en donner une critique et une défense. [...]
thesis.creator: Grimes, Evie M.
thesis.contributor: Walter, H. & Harkness, J. & Du Roure, R. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: French.
thesis.title: L'element lyrique dans les drames de Victor Hugo.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The world has passed through four stages in its dealings with the criminal- (I) the era of vengeance or retribution, (2) of repression, (3) of attempted reformation, and (4) the present era of prevention. (I). The lex talionis was the foundation of the penal codes. Retaliation was recognized as a private right but vengeance was limited to the infliction of an exact equivalent of the injury received. (2) As the power of the State grew, retaliation became more and more a public duty and the Mosaic Code was gradually modified by thepractice of sanctuary and by the system of composition for injuriessuch as Wergeld- a certain sum of money paid as compensation for a certain injury, (3). Under the feudal system the Church and the State gained control of the punishment of crime. [...]
thesis.creator: Going, Margaret C.
thesis.subject: Sociology.
thesis.title: Prisons and prison reform, with special reference to the United States.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
